div.head: THE TURKISH DANGER.
div.p: In a leading article published yesterday, our contemporary "L'Egypte" makes the somewhat astonishing assertion that the question of Akaba (or rather of Tabah) is no longer so Egyptian question. "The prosperity of the Country," we are informed, 'is not bound up with the possession of the kilometres of sand and pebbles contained in the triangle Suez-Akaba-El-Areesh." In our opinion this view is not only mistaken but dangerous. It is all very well to assert that the Sinai is a useless possession and that Europe can be relied upon to keep watch and ward over the Suez Canal, but in our opinion such an assertion betrays a curious blindness to certain military and political factors which most be reckoned with in any appreciation of the actual situation. Assuming that the Powers are ready to prevent any interference with the Suez Canal, is it so certain that they will be able to do so if the Sinai becomes an Ottoman sandjak and the Eastern bank of the Canal is commanded by forts? Are they, singly or collectively, ready to maintain squadrons in the vicinity of Port Said and Suez to guard against a coup de main ? Are they all prepared to give guarantees that no military operations whatever shall be carried on in that narrow ditch and its immediate neighbourhood ? Will France, Italy, or Germany, if engaged in any European or in any important colonial conflict, agree to immobilize a part of their naval forces which may be required elsewhere ? We greatly doubt it and hold rather that there is nothing to prevent the Turks, once established in Sinai, from csing any opportunity afforded them by a European conflict or political crisis to present the guarantors with a fait accompli—nothing, that is, except the local resistance that each action would inevitably provoke. Again, if ships of war daring a naval campaign can pass through the canal, provided that they maintain its neutrality, cannot armies cross it under the same conditions ? England landed troops at Ismailia in 1882: what-but the Egyptian forces, in which we include the Army of Occupation—could prevent Turkey following England's example and justifying the action by British precedents ? It may be urged that we are imputing wildly ambitious designs to an Empire which has been declared moribund for generations. In our opinion the losses of Turkey in Europe have been counterbalanced by her gains in Asia, and while we hope that the Porte has no designs on Egypt, we cannot but recognise that the proverb, "the appetite grows with eating," is peculiarly applicable to nations and Empires, The Ottoman Oliver Twist, after munching the dry cracknel of the Sinai Peninsula, may ask for more refreshing food, and be is in a far better position that his parallel to gratify his desires. Again, is there no truth in all we have heard of the Pan-Islamio movement which aims at freeing all Moslem lands from foreign domination or foreign influence and grouping j them round the holy banner of the Imam of Istamboul ? Our contemporary declares that it sees no sign of agitation even among the most declared Egyptian Nationalists. We differ, but instead of discussing a subject that requires singularly cautious treatment we should like to ask our contemporary what would be the political consequences to Egypt of the occupation of the Sinai peninsula by Ottoman troops. Would the Opposition maintain its absolute calm ? Would every malcontent retrain from the temptation to demand or scheme for Ottoman support against the existing order ? Would Egyptian prestige and the prestige of the Power that occupies a peculiarly important position with regard to Egypt, be unabated by the surrender ? Would the Bedouins, as inhabitants of the Sinai peninsula, appreciate their new masters ? Above all, would the steady commercial development of the country, a development fostered by the isolation and the calm of Egypt, continue with Turkish troops encamped on the frontiers and the country troubled by a haunting sense of military and political insecurity ? Others may declare that the cession of Sinai would make no difference to the tranquility aid prosperity of Egypt. We admire their optimism. The eminent philosopher Pangloss must have founded a school in Egypt during his varied and distressing Oriental experiences, and his spiritual descendants,like their master, appear to enjoy rowing a Turkish calque.

div.head:
THE SINAI QUESTION.
BRITISH CABINET MEETS
THE BOUNDARY PILLARS INCIDENT.
FRANCE TO SUPPORT ENGLAND.
div.p: London, April 28.

The Sinai question was considered at the Cabinet meeting to day and it was decided to despatch the Minerva to El Areesh to inveati gate the removal of the boundary pillars. Meanwhile negotiations are proceeding between here and Constantinople. The Government are fally determined to insist on the Turks withdrawing from Egyptian territory. The Malaooa will embark 3G0 men of the Sassez Regiment at Malta on Sanday for Crete, whence they will take 420 of the Inniskiilings to Alexandria. (Reuter)
Paris, April 29.
The "Temps" publishes an article deolaring that France will heartily support England in the Turco-Egyptian imbroglio as England did France at Algeciras. (Reuter)

Ghazi Mukhtar Pacha has been very anxious about the removal of the boundary pillars at El Areesh. The Ghazi wired to the Porte and has received the following telegram in reply from The Grand Viz«er :— "It is impossible to credit the news that the Ottoman troops have removed thS frontier pillars, whereon the Khedive's name is engraved. Some other persons may have done so to serve their own ends. The Government has ordered the Mutassarifiet of Jerusalem to oped an enquiry into the question and to put back the pillars in their proper place." This telegram was shown by the Pacha to the Khedive. A telegram, published by "Al Lewa," states that The Ottoman troops are now at the gates of El Areesh.

div.p: (From our Correspondent).

H.M.S. Minerva left here under forced steam yesterday evening for El Areesh in connection with the trouble there. On Friday morning she received notice to hold herself in readiness to sail at one hour's notice, ^She is expeoted to return with despatches on Monday

div.head: INCREASE OF THE GARRISON.
div.p: The 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers embarked at Malta yesterday on the S.S. City' of Athens fox Alexandria. Three companies of the 2nd Battalion Royal Sassex Regiment also embarked at Malta yesterday on the S.S. Malaooa for Crete, where they will relieve the three companies of the 2nd Battalion Royal Innis- killing Fusiliers, who will afterwards come on by the Malacca to Alexandria.
The Sultan and the Ghazi.

It is stated at Constantinople that theJ Sultan is very satisfied with Ghazi Mokhtar Pacha's services in the Sinai Peninsula question, knd has refused to listen to some jealous functionaries' advice, wishing to induce him to take back again his splendid gift of No. 3 Palace. It is also stated that the Sultan oannot understand the British pretensions on land belonging to the Ottoman Empire.
Increase of the Garrleon.

Mr. Morley's feelings must be of a sardonic character, says the "Pall Mali Gazette," when, after so many sermons on the subjeot of evacuation, he finds himself in a Government which is increasing The English garrison of Bgyp*. The decision just announced * seems to be entailed at this junoture by * the most elementary prudence. It was stated, in answer to a question in the House of Commons some months ago, that the number of British troops in Egypt was only 3,500, and if there have been any subsequent additions to their strength, the fact has escaped our notice. At a time when the Egyptian authorities are involved in friction with the bead of the Mohamedan world, it is well that a Mohamedan soldiery should be "stiffened" with a morb liberal baoking of British bayonets.
Then and Now.

It is worth recalling as a sample of the whirligig of politics that nearly seventy years ago our Foreign Office was as much concerned in Protecting the frontier of Turkey of against the pensions of the ruler of Egypt as it now is in protecting the Egyptian fontier against the claims of the Sultan. The problem was quite as difficult and then as now and Lord Palmerston The clear that the only solution out of the difficulty was to make Mohammed Aly "With draw into his original shell of Egypt." The cabinet was then convinced that egypt's independence of the port would be most unwise and Lord Palmerston wrote to Lord Granville in 1833. "We are prepared to give naval aid to the Sulton against Mohamed Aly, if necessary and demanded; And we intend to order our Mediterranean fleet immediately to Alexandria in order to get Mohamed aly an outward and visible sign of war inward resolve.
Turkey a Cat's Paw.

The foreign office deserves no small credit, says the "Globe" for defying radical wrath by deciding to augment the British garrison in Egypt. Were there nothing more than the impudent Turkish intrusion in the Sinaticpeninsula, a naval demonstration off the Ottoman littoral would probably suffice to warn off Sultan Abdul Hamid from such dangerous adventures. But the august inmate of Yildiz Kiosk is, in Con tinental opinion, nothing more than the puppet of Germany: By methods and means which can only be conjectured, German influ ence has latterly become dominant at Constantinople, and it is an open secret on the Golden Horn that 'he Kaiser employs it for the farthe ranoe of diplcmstio intrigues, partly direoted, as in the case of Morocoo, to weaken the Anglo Pronoh ent-nte. It is not a olever policy on the part of & tuonarch who aspires to a ropntatiQd for omnisoience; the best that can he said for it is that it may momentarily divert Teutonic thoughts from The growing isolation of the Fatherland. That one palliation if the blander a till rests on chance, and judging from the unea siness evinced by the leading journals at Ber tin, it seems a safe conolasion that the average German does not in the least relish the inter national beyoott ot his beloved country. In any case, our coarse is so c'early traced that Sir E. Grey would have no excase were ho to turn to the right or to the left even by a hair's breadth. With the consent of oolleotive Europe, Great ^Britain has accepted responsibility for both the safety and efficient administration of The Khedive's dominions. It is a sacred trast, afijfthe Kaiser should know that its obligations will be fulfilled as faithfully in the foture as has been the case ever since England took charge of the nearly ruined country.

div.head: SUDAN AND CONGO.
div.p: We understand that the report that Lews Henry Pasha, Slatin Pasha, and Bimb'whj Amery have left Khartoum for Gondokoro to take over the posts in the Bahr El Gliszal evacuated by the troops of the Congo State, in accordance with the provisional agreement concluded with the Sudan Government, is incorrect These officers are going up tho White Nile on a tour of inspection and will visit Lado, where they will hand letters to the Commandant of the Congolese forces in that district officially informing him of the removal of the embargo on steamors and communications pasting between The Sudan and the district occupied by The Congo post. The Sudan Government has communioated to the Press an official notice of the removal of The restrictions imposed some months ago.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL
div.p: On Saturday the Legislative Council approved the declaration of wireless telegraphy a state monopoly and expressed its condolences with the family of the late Sheikh el Saadat

div.head: CRISIS IN ARMENIAN COMMUNITY
div.p: A crisis has taken place in the relations between the Armenian community and the Council of that body in Alexandria. It appears that for some time back the members of the community have been expressing their dissatisfaction with The actions of the present CooDoil, of which Bartan Pacha is the president, and agitating for the election of a new Council by popular vote.

The Archbishop, who had come down from Cairo a fortnight ago for the purpose of settling the dispute, had to far been unsuccessful, and there was an anticipation of some trouble at the church yesterday, which was not wholly unjustified. At noon a deputation of Armenians waited on H.R the Governor at the Goa-vernorat and set forth their grievances, as a result of which his Excellency took immediate aation. Representatives of the Gouveinorat, headed by Heddaya Bey, proceeded to the Armenian Church, and cealed The doors of The sacred edifice, as well as thoee of the Armenian school and the bishop's residence, afterwards handing over The keys to the representatives of the people, who will see to the election of a new Counoil.
Subsequently a number of Armenians,beaded by the band of the community, marched to the Gouvernorat and made a demonstration.
We believe that the Bishop is so prostrated at the tarn events have taken that he is now in the European Hospital.

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: Saturday's bulletin reports 2 fresh cases and 6 deaths in hospital at Deshna, 11 cases and 3 deaths in hospital at Samalout 1 case and 1 death in hospital at Tantah, 1 case and 1 death in hospital and 5 deaths outside hospital at Ghirgeb.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
ARRIVAL AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: H.H. the Khedive left Cairo at 7.45 o'clock this morning for Alexandria. Guards of honour chosen from the Egyptian Army and the Army of Occupation were present at the station to pay the usual honours, and the Railway Administration had taken great pains to decorate the interior and exterior of the station buildings with excellent results. A great number of prominent officials and notables, with many representatives of the Press, were present, besides all the Ministers, the Advisers cud Under Secretaries of State, heads of departments, etc.

His Highness arrived at the station from Koubbeh by special train shortly after halfpast seven and immediately left the train, standing for some time on The platform, conversing with the Ministers and Advisers, and many of the notables present

The guards of honour were drawn up within the station, the Inniskillings on one platform and the Egyptian troops on the other, and the Kbedivial salute was given as his Highness entered and left the station, and a salute of 21 guns being fired from the Citadel as the train steamed out.

The Khadivial train arrived at the Mohar-rem Bey terminus punctually to the minute at 11.30 o'clock, and a salute of 21 guns from Kom el Dik announced the arrival of the train. The station had been very tastefully decorated in honour of the occasion and there was a display of abruba and bunting. A large and representative gathering of European and native notables were assembled on the platform to greet his Highness,who on detraining. walked up the platform, cordially shaking many of those present by the hand.

Oataide the station a guard of honour of Egyptian troops, compoeed of 100 non-commissioned officers and men, the battalion Colon r, and the In tan try band, was paraded, and a similar guard of honour from the British garrison was also paraded.

The Khedive, on leaving the station, inspected the two guards of honour and then dro'e off to Ras el Tin Palace, escorted by his body goard. The streets on The line of route to The Palace were gaily deoorated with flags and bunting, and Cherif Pasha-street pre eented a most animated appearanoe.

While the Khedive was entering his oarriage on leaving the station a European came up behind the carriage with his right hand buried in his breast pceketThe suspicions of Benednoci Bey, Secretary to the Governor of Alexandria, were aroosed as he thooght the man was about to draw a weapon. The Bey se'zed his hand and found it contained a petition. Hehsnded the man over to the police. The petition was consigned to an officer of the Khedive's snife.
The ships in harboor were dressed, as also were the signalling station and The lighthouse.
On his Highness reaching Ras el-Tin Palace, a salute of 21 gone was fired by both Fort Saleh and the American cruiser Tacoma.

His Highness's reception, the last of the season, at Abdeen Palace on Saturday was largely attended, native and European notables alike being well represented. The Khedive, who seemed in good health, conversed for seme time with the Govornor of the National Bank of Egypt, who sat next to the throne chair.
His Highness will in all probability remain for a month at Alexandria.

div.head: ENGLISHMEN DROWNED
div.p: This morning Thomas Frederick Varney, an English employed of Messre. The Cook & son, in their Cairo office, while bathing in the Nile, just below the bridge, was carried away by the current, which is very strong at that point The unfortunate man was carried under the dahabieh from which he bad been bathing and drowned before the few people who were in the neighbourhood at that hour realised the darger.
The body was recovered shortly afterwards and an inquest will be held at the British Consolate to day.

The Naples correspondent of-the "Gioroale d'Italia" says that Mr. Robert Taylor, an Englishman from Alexandria, was gettirg ont of a boat which had brought him whore from a steamer when he fell into the sea. He was rescued in a serions state of asphyxiation, aodjacoording to a Renter's message, snbse-queifly died at the Pellegrini Hospital

div.head: DEATH OF MR WM. HOUGHTON
div.p: Mr. William Houghton died in Cairo on Friday night. The deceased had led a chequered and adventurous life in South Africa and Abyssinia. His pen was forcible and vigorous, his criticism always personal and often witty, and his knowledge of men and things was extensive and peculiar. He died at the age of 56 and was buried in the old cemetery at Old Cairo on Saturday. We tender our sincere condolences to his widow.

For some years past Mr.Houghton took ophis residenceatCairoand was connected with varioas joarnalistio enterprises suoh as the "Times of of Egypt" and the "Egyptian Graphio," none of which, however, can be said to have been in any degree successful. One of his journalistic eoterpri-es was the foundation of' TheCornet" newspaper at Kimberley about 1882. It had only a short but very fiery career. He was also conneoted with Abyssinian polities and occupied a high position in the army of the Negus at one time, and was one of the few British subjects who suoneeded io making themselves the subject of a Blue Book. He had a most varied career and many stories of bis adventures in out-of-the-way parts of the world are current.

div.head:
L'UNION FONCIERE D'EGYPTE
PROGRESS OF THE COMPANY.
div.p: We recently re recived an enquiry from London as to the position of the Union Fon-eiere d'Egypte, and the following statement as to the progress of the company has been com piled. The doings of the company are remarkably little known, even at Alexandria, and this account therefore should be of interest to all those who are on tho kok-oot for a safe investment, as is evident from the following summary of its operations.

At the commencement of the company's career (it was only formed last Jane),an ostate of two thoasand feddans was bought. The price paid was LB. 50 per fsddan. The company has since then considerably improved The land and has already been offered L.B. 85 per feddan for the property. Bat it is hoped that far higher prioes will be realised and the company reoently sold sixteen feddans of this land at L.R lGO. This is a good example of the operations of the company, all of whose real propery purchases-have been characterised by foresight

The Union Fonciere has taken over 7,000 feddans from the Behera Company. Every year the latter company reclaims large arees of uncultivated land, bat has no time to devote to completing the caltivation of the soil. This development work is undertaken by the Union Foncire, which has solectcd from among the Behera estates nearly seven thousand feddans at a price averagii g LE 36 per feddan. This property has been oarefnlly selected at ohoice sites, and it is fully expected that it will bt> eventually sold at L E.80 per feddan.

The third operation made by the Union was The purchase of an estate of aboot six hundred feddans, situated near one of the plots bought from tha Behora Company. The contiguity of the new purchase has greatly benefited the latter plots owing to the facilities for irrigation that have ensued.
The total ooet of the company's purchases up to date amounts to about L.E. 400,000. If the ostates thus purchased were told dow a nett profit of L.E. 160,000 could easily be realised.
The balance (LK ICO,COO) of the oapital remaining is to be laid ont on the purchase of building lands, and at the present time some big sales are being negotiated at Alexandria.

The company's business is being administered mosteoononiioally.lt is entrusted to capable natives, who, it is interesting to note, have turned ont to be most nsefal employer. They keep in touch with the Moudirieh authorities and .other proviooial ooUbilities far better than Europeans wonld and they have been foned to be very serviceable in making bargains with qatives.
The company's lands are aitoated in seven or eight different places, all in the Qharbieh province, which is the most populous moddirieh in Egypt
The foregoing facts show that the company is in a highly satisfactory state. It is under the management of M. Leopold Jollies, whose reputation as an expert in land is well known.

The Union Fonciere d'Egypte received the Khedivial sanction on the 6th Jane hat and op to the present The company has received little attention from the speculative public, despite the faot that it is in a very flourishing• condition and has done a great deal of excellent business. The oapital is £600,000 in 100,000 shares of £6 each, and was subscribed as follows The Anglo-Foreign Banking Company Limited, £20,000 ; P. P. Rodooanaehi & Co., £10,000 ; Socidtd Marseillaise de Crédit Indmtriel et Commercial et de D4p6ts,£3O,CO0; Zifiropoolo and Zarifi, £20,COO ; J. Aghion e figlio, £140,000 ; C. M. Salvago & Oo., £140,000 ; C. G. Zirvndaohi & fils, £140,000 ; The 6,000 founders shares were their distributed : The Anglo Foreign Banking Company, Limited, 200-; P, P. Rodooanaohi & Co., %C0 ; Sooidtd Marseillaise de Crédit InBustriel et Commercial et de DdpOts, 400 ; Zafiropoelo and Zarifi, 400 ; J. Aghion e figlio, 1,284; C. M. Salvago & Co, 1,255; C. G. Zerrodaohi & fils, 1,258.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Baron de Kusel Bey, general manager of the Egyptian Trust & Investment, Limited, left Port Said this monrng by the Brindisi mail $n route for London. We understand that his visit is connected with the company's business but that his absentee will be of very short duration, as he expeota to be back again in Egypt within the next three weeks.

The saloons of the New Khedivial Hotel ware thronged on Saturday with members of the fashionable society of Alexandria present at the reception given on the occasion of the marriage of Miss lieline Pantaxides to Mr. A. Qiro. The religious oeremony had pre* viously taken place at the Evangelismoe Cathedral. Among those present wa noticed H. E. the Governor, Mr. K B. Gould, Ijl.O., H.B.M'e Consnl-Ge >eral, and Mrs. Gould, M.iP. Girard, French Consnl-General, and Mme Girard, the Austro-Hnngarian Vioe-Consnl, etc.
Mr. E. A. Harrison, general manager Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son (Egypt), Limited leaves for Europe by the P. & 0. Oaled on Monday next.

div.head: GRANDS GARAGES D'EGYPTE
div.p: C'est demain que doit avoir lien l'émission de la Société Anonyme des Grands Garages d'Egypte, société qui a été autorisée par Déoret Khédivial en date da 23 Avril courant, et dont les fondateurs sont M M J.W. Williamson, Allan Joseph, Alfred G. Curphey, P.W. Stout, E.C. Hogg, Alex. Comanos et Georges Merzbach.
Le premier conseil d'administration des Grands Garages est composé de MM. J. W. Williamson, Allan F. Joseph, Pierre de Bois-sien et Angaste Faget.

Le but de la Société est la reprise à la société Anonyme Egyptienne d'électricité de son garage situé an Caire, quartier Marouf, y compris toutes les installations, stocks, etc, ainsi que les agences des Maisons qu'elle représente, notamment celles de la Compagnie parisienne des Voitures Eleotriques (Krieger) et de la Compagnie Richard Brasier, dont la renommée est universelle.

Cotre la vente des voitures, qui de jour en jour prend une grande extension, la Société tirera évidemment de gros revenus de la location ; le genre d'affaire qui n'a été fait jasqu'ici que par des particuliers ne disposant généralement que de moyens limités, a donné des résultats absolument inattendus ; on peut donc s'attendre à voir la Société qui aura à sa disposition des capitanx considérables, en tirer des bénéfices partioalièrement importants.

La Société compte établir également un second garage au Caire, dans l'ile de Ghézireh, et un autre à Alexandrie. Elle pourra, bien entendu, en installer d'autres partout où elle jugera utile et avantageux de le faire.

De plus, une école de chauffeurs sera très probablement ouverte, ce qui viendra combler une lacune ; en effet, il n'est guère pratique de faire venir, à grands frais, des mécinioiens d'Europe, alors que sous la conduite de bons professeurs, nombre d'indigènes ou d'européens dp pays, deviendront de parfaits chauffeurs ; ceux-ci trouveront ainsi des emplois rémunérateurs, tout en faisant réaliser aux propriétaires de voitures une sériease économie.

Etant donné le développement considérable qu'a pris l'automobilisme en Egypte, il n'est pas difficile de prévoir le vaste champ d'opération qu'a devant elle une exploitation telle que celle de la Société des Grands Garages.

La Société est constitué a au capital de L E. 80,000 divisé en 20 000 actions de L. E. 4 chacune, sur lesquelles la moitié seulement, soit 10.000 actions sont offertes au public. La souscription ne sera ouverte que demain, à l'Anglo Egyptian Bank au Caire et à Alexandrie. P. T. 50 sont payables à la souscription, et P. T. 50 à la répartition. Pour chaque 10 actions, il sera alloué une part de fondateur.
Les souscriptions seront reçues, tant au Caire qu'à Alexandrie, aux guichets de l'Anglo Egyptian Bank. Nous publions d'autre part le prospeotus d'émission.

div.head: LES SOCIETES IMMOBILIERES
div.p: Le Journal Officiel de Samedi publie, en supplément, le Décret Khédivial autorisant la création de "The Cairo Suburban Building Lands Compary", Société Anonyme ou capital de L. E. 160000 divisé en 40000 actions ordinaires de L. E. 4 chacune. Sur celles-ci, 14000 actions seront offertes à la souscription publique, le Mercredi 2 Mai, aux guichets de l'Anglo Egyptian Bank au prix de L. E 4 1/4.

Le Champ d'action de la Société est des plus grands. Elle pourra acheter, vendre ou prendre à bail tous immeubles, les mettre en valeur, y édifier des constructions, les revendre au comptant ou à terme, les louer, etc.; elle pourra également s'occuper de toutes entreprises de travaux publics ou privés. La Société est déja propriétaire, entre le pont de Ghamrah et Demerdache, d'une vaste étendue de terrain au milieu de laquelle sera établie une gare do nouveau chemin de fer de la Cairo Electric Railways and Oases Cy. qui y amènera les voyageurs du pont Limoun en moins de 5 minutes.

Mais nous croyons savoir que, loin de s'en tenir à ce seul domaine, la Société a en vae d'autres affaires similaires, et qu'elle compte bénéficier, dans une très large proportion, du développement économique du pays. Il est facile de se rendre compte que, bien que son activité doive se limiter au Caire et à sa banlieue, l'extension extraordinaire que prend la Capitale, la construction de quartiers nouveaux, l'avantage considérable qu'il y a à acheter des terrains en gros pour les lotir, tout cela suffira à lui assurer un vaste champ de travail.

Le Conseil d'Administration de la nouvelle Société est composé d'hommes compétents et pratiques, qui, tant par leur connaissance approfondie du pays que par leurs relations et leurs capacités, sont à même de pouvoir assurer à l'entreprise, les meilleurs résultats.
Nous publions d'autre part, le prospectus d'émission.

div.head: Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotment Co.
div.p: Le Conseil d'Administration a l'honneur d'informer M.M. les Actionnaires que le 1er Mai prochain expire le délai fixé par les Statuts pour le paiement du 4e versement qui est d'une livre égyptienne par action.
Tout versement en retard est assujetti, de plein droit, en faveur de la Société, à un intérêt de 7 %.
L'Anglo-Egyptian Bank est chargée de recevoir les versements et d'en donner quittance sur le certificat provisoire. 27788 3a 2

div.head: DECES
div.p: Nous avons le regret d'annoncer la mort de Mme Jeanne Spada, survenue ce matin à 2 b. Le convoi funèbre partira cet après-midi à 5 heures de la maison mortuaire, sise rue Anastasi, N60.
Nous adressons à la famille éplorée nos vifs sentiments de condoléances.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: La Caire, Samedi le 28 avril. Le taux do l'escompte à Londres vient d'être réduit de 1/8 à 3 3/8 pour cent. Hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé de 1/4 à 9 5/8. L'Unifiée a baissé de 1/8 à 106 1/8. La National Bank a olôturé avec 1/8 de reprise à 26 1/2. L'Agricole a gagné 1/4 à 10 3/8 et la Delta Light 3/8 à 12 5/8. La Daïra est restée itvariée à 17 5/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier a perdu 1 franc à 779. La Banque d'Athènes est demeurée inchangée à 152.

Giâse aux coars de clôture de Londres, nous avons en, ce matin, un bon marché. La tendance à la fermeté qui s'é'ait dessinée hier s'est vivement accentuée au début de la séance, et il y a eu reprise sur les valeurs partioalièrement atteintes ces jours-oi. La olôture a été toutefois moins satisfaisante.

La National Bank a progressé jusqu'à 26 11/16 pour olôturer à 26 5/8. Eu bonne tendance, l'Agricole a également avancé jaequ'à 10 3/16 pour finir à 10 3/32. Le Comptoir Financier s'est insorit à 7 11/16.
L'action Crédit Foncier est revenue à 782. La Daïra a fait 17 1/2, la Béhéra 35 1/2-36, et la Delta Light 12 7/16.
Les jouissances Eaux da Caire ont avancé à 268-269.
La part de fondateur Wardan Estate a progressé à 8 3, 4 et l'action Nile Land à 14 3/4.
Les Omnibus ont eu les honneurs de la matinée : des achats suivis les ont fait monter de £28 1/2 à 31 1/2. Les Automobiles ont, d'autre part, haussé de £ 6 à 6 7/8.
L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux s'est raffermie à 4 7/16 ; la part de fondateur est restée à 76.
L'action Héliopolis a été traitée à 323. La Khedivial Mail a gagné 2 sh. à 37.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Ba h'er ont clôturé à 5 1/16 1/8 et les Upper Egypt sont remontés à 4 11/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, il y a eu un bon courant d'affaires en Delta Land, qui ont atteint 4 13/16 pour clôturer à 4 3/4, et en Estates qu'on a poussés jusqu'à 1 15/16; la part de fondateur a haussé à £ 12. Les Hooker ont fait l 1/161/8, les Glymenopoulo 1 9/16-5/8 et les Walker and Meimarachi £ 013/16-7/8.
Nous rappelons que la souscription aux ac tions de la Sooiété des Excelsior Hotels sera ouverte lundi matin 30 Avril à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank et clôturée le même jour à 5 h. p.m.

C'est à mardi prochain 1er Mai qu'est fixée l'émission des Grands Garages d'Egypte, Société anonyme autorisée par décret khedivial, au capital da LE 80,000 divisé en 20,000 actions ordinaires de LE. 4 chacune. Il est, en outre, créé 10,000 parts de fondateur.

La Société a pour objet l'établissement, l'achat et l'exploitation de garages pour automobiles, la représentation de fabriques d'automo biles, l'achat, la vente et la location d'automobiles, en général l'industrie de l'automobile en Egypte et toutes opérations accessoires, notamment celles concernant le nettoyage par tous procédés.
Ou voit que la création de la nouvelle Société répond à un besoin réel, étant donné l'essor extraordinaire que l'automobilisme prend dans ce pays.
Le premier Conseil d'administration des Grands Garages est composé de MM. J. W. Williamson, Allan F. Joseph, Pierre de Boissieu et Auguste Faget.

Il est offert au public 10.000 actions ordinaires au pair. La souscription ne sera ouverte qu'un seul jour, à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank au Caire et à Alexandrie. Il sera alloué une part de fondateur pour chaque dix actions ordinaires.
Il s'agit d'une excellente affaire, et nous nous mettons volontiers à la disposition de ceux de nos clients qui voudraient souscrire par notre entremise.

Ou sait que l'assemblée extraordinaire de la Nungovich Hotels Co. a décidé, le 17 du courant, l'augmentation du capital social par la création de 9,500 notions nouvelles réservées aux porteurs actuels à raison d'une action non velle pour trois anciennes. Or, les aotionnaires, qui voudraient user de leur droit de préférence sont invités à déposer leurs titres, accompagnés du premier versement, à la National Bank of Egypt du 1er au 15 Mai prochain.
Le prix d'émission est fixé à £ 12, payables 4 à la souscription, 4 le 15 Mai et le solde le 1er Novembre prochain.
On annonce que l'émission de l'Egypt and Levaut Steamship Co. a été couverte environ 12 fois entre le Caire et Alexandrie.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: There is a vacancy in the Sudan Medical Department for a young medical man who must be fully qualified and should be between 23 and 27 years of age. One having a previous hospital appointent will be preferred.
He must speak English and Arabic and be either of Egyptian or Syrian nationality. A Mohammedan by preference.
Pay commences at L E. 20 per mensem with increases after satisfactory service at stated intervals.
Copies of three testimonials should be sent to :— Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum.

as soon as possible with application in applicants own handwriting stating age, experience, Medical School and any further particulars which may assist in the choice of a man. One of the testimonials should be from an English-man if possible.
Sudan AGENCY. Cairo, 27th April, 1905, 27813 3-A-l

div.head: Alexandria General Produce Association

div.p: Questionnaire d'Avril 1906. (Prière de répondre avant le Mai en vous servant de la langue que vous préférez).
1. — Les semailles sont-elles terminées dans votre Markas ? et dans votre Province ? A-t-on semé plus on moins que l'année dernière ?
2. — Combien de Coton Abassi et Joanovich a-t-on semé, en plus on en moins que l'année passée?
3 — Les semailles ont-elles été anticipées ? ou faites a l'époque ordinaire? ou retardées? (et pour quels motifs?
4. — Les jeunes plantes sont-elles très avancées ? sont-elles en bon état ? on ont-elles été contrariées par quelque circonstance? (et laquelle ?)
5. — Combien pour cent de terrain semé en Coton a-t on dû resemer ? a-t-on dû resemer plusieurs fois ?
6. — L'eau pour les irrigations est-elle abondante ? on bien est-elle suffisante ? ou bien est elle insuffisante ?
7. — Les vers ont iis apparu dans votre district? et ont ils attaqué les Cotonniers ?
Pour le Comité (Le Président) C. de Tschudi.

div.head: THE ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY AND THE POWERS.*
div.p: Before the railway, the trade between Abyssinia and the coast was mostly carried by caravan to the port of Zeila in British Somali-land. In all probability, when once the railway was working it would acquire most of the traffic, but this was not good enough for the French Minister, and he got Menelik to give orders that all merchandise leaving Harrar or coming there from the coast should be carried exclusively by the railway, thus diverting the whole of the trade from the British port. The concessionaries thus started under very good auspices, but they found the difficulty of obtaining their capital in Paris greater than they expected, and it was not until 1897 that some French banks took a considerable amount of their shares and bonds, and the French Government agreed to collect at Djibouti a 10 per cent. duty on the goods to be transported by the railway. The work was also begun in 1897, and such an enterprise naturally attracted great attention in French colonial circles ; it was pointed out that Abyssinia was a country of vast resources, both mineral and agricultural, and that the railway monopoly in French hands would open an immense field for French capital and a certain amount of political control. that Djibouti might not unreasonably be expected to supplant Aden, as the principal port of call for Far Eastern trade ; it was not enough to say how good it would be for French trade, but a great point was made of the way in which British trade was to suffer. These favoured circumstances brought for a time great prosperity to Djibouti, and much capital was Spent there in view of its magnificent future prospects ; the town increased by leaps and bounds ; but as years went on and the railway works progressed it began to be seen, as is usual in such cases, that the difficulties of the task had been underrated ; the estimated cost had been largely exceeded ; the tribesmen, who saw in perspective the destruction of their carrying trade, gave trouble, they not only attacked working parties, but at one time threatened even Djibouti itself; the company and their contractors quarrelled, the latter had probably not undertaken to wage war; the funds waned to a low ebb, and attempts to replenish them in France met with scant success. Although endeavours were made to excite patriotic emotions, on the grounds of political influence, they did not materialize in the form of financial assistance, and although the directors were all Frenchmen, they found themselves compelled to look elsewhere for support.

It was only from a speech delivered in 1900, by the chairman of the New African Company, that the public was first informed that British capital had become interested in this railway. He no doubt wished to justify his policy and that of his colleagues by saying all that he could in favour of it, but it sounds rather like faint praise when he feels obliged to qualify bis hopes that the business will be profitable, by saying that it is "subject to the vicissitudes in new railway undertakings of this nature,'' At all events the New African Company advanced a large sum of money to the railway company, and it may be news to some of oar readers to hear that this was followed by another amount advanced by the New Egyptian Company. Most of ns thought that the shareholders of Egyptian companies invested their capital in this country, but it appears that is only an old fashioned idea, — it is now used "orbi et urbi" ; if Egypt is too small for them, would it not be better to take a more ambitions name ?

A year later — in 1901—it was officially announced that three British companies had considerably extended their interest in the railway, but for some time an uneasy feeling had been growing in French colonial circles, that the increase of British capital might in-teifere with the exclusively French character of the enterprise ; a violent outcry was raised to the effect that French interests were betrayed, and that once more rapacious England was seeking to supplant France. Nothing was said about the co-operation of British capital, having being invited when both the French investor and his Government bad declined to copie to the rescue, and the whole enterprise was on the point of collapse.

After many efforts, in which no attempt was made to conceal their ultimate object, the French Colonial party succeeded in obtaining the assistance of the Government in 1903, but this result was not arrived at until an arrangement had been made which entirely changed the whole character of the enterprise, from a commercial to a political undertaking, The authors description of this phase of the business is most interesting, and it is simply astounding to find that in all the long negotiations which led up to it the French Government and the company made the unpardonable blunder of not consulting Menelik at all in the matter, although he was admittedly an independ(nt Sovereign whose rights the French Government were taking from a com- pany which had no such rights to concede. However well pleased the French Government might have been with this arrangement, we think that on reflection the directors of the company could have had but little reason to be thankful ; they were tied hand and foot ; they could not even appoint their own manager or local representatives without the consent of a French Minister, and the latter could at any time demand their resignation. We only quote one of a series of vexations regulations, which appear sufficient to make life unbearable and progress almost impossible.

However anxious the Emperor Menelik was to see the railway finished, it was too much to expect that a man of his intelligence, character, and position was going to put up with this sort of neglect, without having some thing to say about it. Menelik has in recent times acquired, not at little cost, a much wider outlook, and a deeper insight into international relations, than he formerly possessed ; a long series of events had not passed unobserved by him, the author refers to many of them at some length, but we will only mention one or two, which certainly produced some effect on the mind of the Emperor. He had listened to the proposals of the French Minister that he should co-operate with France in ambitions schemes on the Upper Nile Valley ; Kitchener's decisive victory at Omdurman and the withdrawal of French troops from Fashoda were in violent contradiction with the probabilities he had been led to believe. The frequent observations in the French Press to the effect that Abyssinia might become "a sort of colony" of France did not pass unnoticed, not could their effect have been a pleasing one on Menelik. At all events, in 1903, when the text of the Convention was published, Menelik declared to the French Minister that its terms filled him with astonishment and indignation, and M. Lagarde's request that he should assent to it met with a fiat refusal; he said that he considered some of its clauses as a direct infringement of his rights as an independent sovereign, and that they unmasked a design of territorial aggrandisement with which he had been unwilling to credit France.

It is not very astonishing that French influence at Adis Abeba fell to something below zero. Meanwhile, the railway company, with the funds raised on the security of the French Government, had paid off the loans contracted with the British companies, and had gone on with the construction of the line, which was completed as far as Dire Daona, a distance of about 195 miles from Djibouti, in December 1902. Great preparations were made for the inauguration, and it was announced that Menelik would be present, bat much to the disappointment of the officials, he did not attend, although it must have been no slight disappointment to have kept away, as he had frequently expressed his strong desire to see the railway and the sea.

New difficulties soon arose, the principal one being Menelik's refusal to give the necessary permission for the continuation of the railway, which he said he could not allow to be built by a company controlled by a foreign Government. This put the company in a very awkward position, their funds were again almost exhausted, the receipts of the line were insufficient to meet its working expenses, interest on lands, etc. A fresh attempt was made to induce the French Government to again come to the rescue of this never so-called national enterprise, but in vain. The company, in its extremity, was again compelled to have recourse to the British group. Long negotiations followed which are difficult to trace, but in December, 1901, the Earl of Cheserfield, as Chairman of the International Trust Company. in his speech to his shareholders.
mentions them at some length, still only in such terms as to show that up to that time no understanding had been arrived at.

Early in 1905 the matter was again brought to the serious attention of the French Government without much result beyond a suggestion that the "entente cordiale" should be brought to bear on it, although, so far as we know, that "entente" had nothing to do with Abyssinia, except perhaps on the principle that "any stick is good enough to beat a dog with." (To be continued).

div.p: The following are the entries for the First Summer Meeting to be held on the A. S. C. grounds on Thursday and Saturday next:— 1st DAY.

2nd DAY

Pony Plate. -Prince Omar Pacha Toussoon's Beylan Baron J. E. de Menasce's Viking ; Hussein Pacha Sioufi's Abou Nadara; Mr. E. Bustros' Temsah ; Mr. E. Karam's Pilote and Shaibonb; Capt. Rome and Capt. Grant's Rainbow ; Khalil Pasha Khayat's Subeil and Kawkab; Ibrahim Bey Cherif's Atbara and Ter el Hamam ; Saleh Bey Yaghen's Siham and Miassar; Mr. A J. Sursock's Ruy Blas.
Grand Prize of Alexandria (Additional entries).—Khalil Pacha Khayat's Au Revoir ; Mr. E. Karam's Nimrod.

Municipal Cup —Ishack Bey Hussein's Farhan II., and Moofid; Mr. P. W. Stout's Shewiman ; Khalil Pasha Khayat's Latiff and Sadik ; Ibrahim Bey Cherit's Valentino ; Mr. A. J. Sursock's Roi de l'Air ; Capt. E. B. Bartlett's g.a.p. Gamechicken.
The following is the programme of music to be performed by the band of the R. Dublin Fusiliers on the second day :—

1. March—Under the Double Eagle—Wagner. 2. Overture—Zampa—Harold. 3. Valse—Rose—Margis. 4. Selection—A Gaiety Girl—Jones. 5. Serenade—Moszowski. 6. Selection—The Geisha—Jones. 7. Valse—Chantilly—Waldteufel. 8. Song.—The Promise of Life—Cowen. 9. Selection—Cavalleria Rusticana—Mascagni. 10. Two Step.—Mumblin'Moss—Thurban.

div.head: RIFLE SHOOTING.
div.p: ALEXANDRIA B.R.C. v. CAIRO B.R.C.

Teams representing these clubs shot off a match at Tourah on Monday, 23rd inst. The shooting was witnessed by several visitors from Cairo, including Mr. and Lady Valda Machell, Mr. Humphreys, and others. Tourah range was at its worst and the visiting team were evidently somewhat at a disadvantage in coping with the variable wind. After being one point down at 200 yards, the home team won by 29 points. Scores :—
The Alexandria team wss entertained by their opponents at dinner in Shepheard's Hotel in the evening.
A. S. C.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: The Company has been formed for the purpose of acquiring, under exceptionally favourable terms and conditions, certain lands situated between the Pont de Ghamrah and Demerdache Railway Station (Egyptian State Railways) which will be brought to within five minutes of the heart of Cairo by the construction at a central point on the Company's Estate of a Station which will be the stopping point on the Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Coy's Line between Font Limoun and the Oasis of Abbassieh.

Other equally—if not more important advantages will accrue to the Lands now acquired, by reason of the probable immediate constrnotion of important thoroughfares passing through the Estate, and joining the Boulevard Abbas, the widening of which is now in active progress, whilst the projected new Avenue to the Palais de Konbbeh will entail the construction of an imposing "passage" at the Font de Gamrah thus bringing that part of the lands purchased situated on the left side of the Matarieh Railway to a point of value almost on a par with the rest of the Estate.

With such physical advantages as those mentioned, in addition to the favourable position occupied by the Estate, it does not require the knowledge of an expert to see that the realisation of it in conveniently sized lots at much enhanced prices will be a matter of comparative ease, particularly in the hands of those immediately connected with the Company, whose experience in this class of business is well-known.

div.head: The whole of the Capital of the Company las been subscribed as follows : —
div.p: Applications for Shares should be made on this special Form, and forwarded, with cheque for the amount payable on application, to the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, LTD, in Cairo or Alexandria.

If the Number of Shares allotted he less than that applied for, the surplus will be credited to the applicant on account of the amount due on allotment, and any further excess will be returned to him.

Failure to pay any instalment when due will render all previous payments liable to forfeiture, and all overdue payments shall bear interest at the rate of 8 % per annum. Cairo, 25th April 1906. 27815-2-1
